articles.headline: China Investigates Contaminated Toothpaste
articles.snippet: More poison-tainted toothpaste has turned up in Latin America, including some made for children.
articles.abstract: More poison-tainted toothpaste has turned up in Latin America, including some made for children.
articles.lead_paragraph: DANYANG, China, May 21 — Chinese authorities are investigating whether two companies from this coastal region exported tainted toothpaste as more contaminated product, including some made for children, has turned up in Latin America.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Walt Bogdanich

articles.headline: Trade Talks With China at a Juncture
articles.snippet: Some question whether efforts to open China to U.S. goods will satisfy a Congress irate over a staggering trade deficit.
articles.abstract: Some question whether efforts to open China to U.S. goods will satisfy a Congress irate over a staggering trade deficit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 21 — In recent weeks, the Bush administration has negotiated furiously with China to secure some eye-catching new agreements to unlock Chinese markets for American goods. China, in response, has told the United States that it plans new purchases of $30 billion — a shopping spree that dwarfs any China has gone on previously.

articles.headline: Baghdad District Is a Model, but Only for Shiites
articles.snippet: In Kadhimiya, which offers Iraqis relative safety, religious Shiite leaders and their militias have consolidated control.
articles.abstract: In Kadhimiya, which offers Iraqis relative safety, religious Shiite leaders and their militias have consolidated control.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, May 18 — Ice cream shops in the Shiite stronghold of Kadhimiya are flush with sweet-toothed customers. Hospitals have new supplies. Rents have tripled as displaced Shiites flock to the historic district’s spacious homes, while pilgrims stream to the golden-domed shrine at its heart.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Damien Cave

articles.headline: Side Deals in a Gray Area
articles.snippet: Correspondence among investors known as “big-boy letters” is about to face its first significant legal challenge.
articles.abstract: Correspondence among investors known as “big-boy letters” is about to face its first significant legal challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Global deal making is on a tear, accompanied by a surge of insider trading cases.

articles.headline: Heart Attack Risk Seen in Drug for Diabetes
articles.snippet: An analysis of trials for Avandia concluded that the drug might significantly increase the risk of heart attacks.
articles.abstract: An analysis of trials for Avandia concluded that the drug might significantly increase the risk of heart attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: An article in a leading medical journal yesterday raised serious safety questions about the widely used diabetes pill Avandia and renewed skepticism about the vigilance of federal drug regulators.

articles.headline: Kerkorian in New Move in Las Vegas
articles.snippet: The latest S.E.C. filing by Kirk Kerkorian’s company has analysts wondering whether the billionaire plans to take MGM private.
articles.abstract: The latest S.E.C. filing by Kirk Kerkorian’s company has analysts wondering whether the billionaire plans to take MGM private.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month Kirk Kerkorian, the 89-year-old billionaire who buys and sells large positions in corporations like few others on Wall Street, offered $4.5 billion to buy Chrysler from DaimlerChrysler, only to lose out to another bidder.
articles.byline: By Gary Rivlin and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Supporters Urge Pakistan Leader to Shift Course
articles.snippet: Gen. Pervez Musharraf is being advised to seek conciliation with opponents or risk losing power.
articles.abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf is being advised to seek conciliation with opponents or risk losing power.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 21 — After a series of political blunders in the last two months, Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, is being advised by his political supporters to make a dramatic change of course or risk losing power amid more chaos and bloodshed.
